Corporate Law as Decolonization
Martin W. Sybblis
ABSTRACT

After centuries of colonial subordination, Black and Brown former colonies are still fighting to achieve the fruits of decolonization. The traditional theory is that former colonies will emerge from the colonial period with the legal mandate and international recognition needed to chart their own futures. But, for those Black and Brown British colonies that achieved political independence, it became clear that, without economic strength to care for their societies, legal separation could not deliver on its promise of freedom from subordination. This Article argues that investments in corporate law innovations by some jurisdictions, such as Bermuda, the British Virgin Islands, and the Cayman Islands, have provided a pathway to postcolonial self-determination. These communities have generated immense wealth and autonomy for their populations in the postcolonial era by using strategies akin to those deployed by the State of Delaware. While former colonizers denigrate Bermuda, the Cayman Islands, and the British Virgin Islands as tax havens and corporate law imperialists, which must be aggressively governed to protect the tax base and financial sectors of "non-tax haven" countries, there is another side to this narrative: Offshore corporate law is freedom-promoting for some communities. This Article complicates the dominant perspective of corporate law imperialism and introduces a conceptualization of corporate law as decolonization to the legal and policy discourse on offshore financial centers.
AUTHOR

Associate Professor of Law, Emory University School of Law; Visiting Fellow, Princeton School of Public and International Affairs (SPIA) (2022-2023). SCHOL OF LNN
INTRODUCTION

Achieving legal and political independence is a significant moment in the history and development of a colony. This is especially the case if the formerly enslaved peoples were able to jettison an exploitative colonial controller. Sovereignty, however, is not always the path chosen when subordinated communities have the opportunity for greater self-determinationbut rather an enhanced ability to pursue their national interests. Indeed, throughout the globe, there remain at least forty nonsovereign jurisdictions.

1. See E. Tendayi Achiume, Migration as Decolonization, 71 STAN. L. REV. 1509, 1528 (2019) (discussing the expectations surrounding the formal decolonization project). In 1960, the UN's Declaration on the Granting of Independence to Colonial Countries and Peoples stated that "[a]ll peoples have the right of self-determination; by virtue of that right they freely determine their political status and freely pursue their economic, social and cultural development." G.A. Res. 1514 (XV), Declaration on the Granting of Independence to Colonial Countries and Peoples (Dec. 14, 1960).

2. See, e.g., Catherine Porter, Constant Mheut, Matt Apuzzo & Selam Gebrekidan, The Root of Haiti's Misery: Reparations to Enslavers, N.Y. TIMES (Nov. 16, 2022), https://www.nytimes.com/2022/05/20/world/americas/haiti-history-colonized-france.html?searchResultPosition=1 [https://perma.cc/4537-RKXE] (discussing the case of Haiti's independence revolution).

3. I use "self-determination" to mean a postcolonial community's enjoyment of a "domination-free and postimperial [domestic] order" that prioritizes the social and economic welfare of their members through increased autonomy over governance. Adom Getachew, WORLDMAKING AFTER EMPIRE: THE RISE AND FALL OF SELF-DETERMINATION 74 (2019). In this regard, I use it in a manner similar to that of political scientist Adom Getachew. According to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, a community's right to self-determination refers to their ability to "freely determine their political status and freely pursue their economic, social and cultural development." G.A. Res. 2200 (XXI) A, International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, art. 1, (Dec. 16, 1966). Importantly, communities have freedom in how they pursue these goals. See, e.g., Achiume, supra note 1, at 1528 (noting that "international law does not require democratic rule at the national level").

4. See, e.g., ELIZABETH DAVIES, THE LEGAL STATUS OF BRITISH DEPENDENT TERRITORIES: THE WEST INDIES AND NORTH ATLANTIC REGION 1-8 (1995) (discussing the decision of several small island colonies in the Commonwealth Caribbean to remain territories of the United Kingdom rather than seek political independence).

5. See, e.g., Malcolm Ferdinand, Gert Oostindie & Wouter Veenendaal, A Global Comparison of Non-Sovereign Island Territories: The Search for 'True Equality,' 15 ISLAND STUD. J., no. 1, 2020, at 43, 43-66.

The choice of nonsovereignty by some jurisdictions,[6] such as the corporate law "market dominant small jurisdictions"[7] (MDSJs) of Bermuda, the British Virgin Islands, and the Cayman Islands should not automatically be interpreted as a failure to achieve the fruits of decolonization. On the contrary, their choice of sub-sovereign status to the United Kingdom (UK) has led to greater autonomy and self-determination than achieved by neighboring sovereign states in the Caribbean.[8] This view of self-determination has less to do with constitutional rights as traditionally understood and more to do with economic success.[9] For some nonsovereign jurisdictions, a keen awareness of neocolonialism has motivated a hyperfocus on economic self-reliance as a vehicle for true self-

6. This Article does not speak to all previously colonized jurisdictions, only those that have or had the ability to choose sovereignty. For example, some jurisdictions were once colonies in the traditional sense but lack the right of self-determination in the postcolonial era. Ferdinand et al. supra note 5, at 48. For example, Hong Kong (formerly a British colony) and Macau (formerly a Portuguese colony), are nonsovereign special administrative regions of China and are "not[] allowed a free choice about their future constitutional status." Id.

7. Corporate law scholar Christopher Bruner coined the term market dominant small jurisdictions (MDSJs) to refer to small jurisdictions that have endured "similar economic development challenges, and have sought to compete in cross-border finance." CHRISTOPHER BRUNER, RE-IMAGINING OFFSHORE FINANCE: MARKET DOMINANT SMALL JURISDICTIONS IN A GLOBALIZING WORLD 41-50 (2016). Not only do MDSJs share similar "geographic and cultural commonalities." Id. at 41. MDSJs have also been exceptionally successful in offshore finance and corporate law. Id. at 42-50. Indeed, they have been globally dominant in these areas. Id. I use this term to refer to Bermuda, the British Virgin Islands, and the Cayman Islands. Other such jurisdictions include, for example, Dubai, Singapore, Hong Kong, Switzerland, and Delaware. Id. at 9.

8. See DAVID A. REZVANI, SURPASSING THE SOVEREIGN STATE: THE WEALTH, SELF-RULE, AND SECURITY ADVANTAGES OF PARTIALLY INDEPENDENT TERRITORIES (2014) (discussing the economic success and autonomy of "partially independent jurisdictions"); GETACHEW, supra note 3, at 107-41 (discussing neocolonialism and the postindependence subordination of Black countries). Scholars have theorized that there is relatively little interest in political independence in these small island jurisdictions because of the tangible benefitsincluding economic support, national security, and right of migrationthat come from their affiliation with powerful countries such as the United States and the United Kingdom. See Ferdinand et al., supra note 5, at 60. There are currently fourteen jurisdictions that are known as "UK Overseas Territories." PHILIP LOFT, HOUSE OF COMMONS LIBR., RSCH. BRIEFING NO. 9706, THE OVERSEAS TERRITORIES: AN INTRODUCTION AND RELATIONS WITH THE U.K. (2023), https://researchbriefings.files.parliament.uk/documents/CBP-9706/CBP-9706.pdf [https://perma.cc/SA3N-ABZ8].
9. See infra Part II and III (discussing the relationship between corporate law, economic growth, and decolonization).
Corporate Law as Decolonization
determination.
For these jurisdictions, political independence without economic strength would provide only the illusion of decolonization.
It would lead to persistent subordination to powerful nations and international organizations.

This Article argues that investments in corporate law provide one pathway to achieving the economic success required for self-determination in the postcolonial era.[13] Conventional conceptualizations of constitutional lawwith prescribed state authority and individual rightsas the vehicle for postcolonial freedom[14] overlook how subordinated communities find alternative ways to conceptualize decolonization.[15] In an environment with an imbalance of power, the weaker community will seek to "mak[e] do with what a situation offers."[16] Thus, it aggressively pursues openings within the prevailing power structure to strengthen its position.[17]

Similarly, a set of majority Black and Brown postcolonial offshore financial centers (OFCs) have effectively demonstrated that corporate law provides a viable path to significant postcolonial autonomyeven in the
10. In this view, "[r]elations of dependence [give] external actors the capacity for arbitrary interference." GETACHEW, supra note 3, at 23.

12. See id. (noting that "[i]n this context, actions that appeared to be the free legislative decisions of an independent state were in fact the result of dependence on other states, private actors, or international organizations"); see also Achiume, supra note 1, at 1539-47 (discussing the concept of "neocolonial imperialism").
13. See infra Parts II and III (discussing how investments in corporate law can help MDSJs to achieve a form of self-determination).

14. In the United States, there is a general understanding that rights and freedoms stem from legal documents, such as constitutions. For example, Cass Sunstein notes that "[t]he United States Constitution in its original form was borne directly out of two experiences: the tyranny of English rule and the inadequacy of the decentralized system created by the Articles of Confederation that preceded the Constitution." CASS R. SUNSTEIN, THE SECOND BILL OF RIGHTS: FDR'S UNFINISHED REVOLUTION AND WHY WE NEED IT MORE THAN EVER 36 (2004).
15. See, e.g., Achiume, supra note 1, at 1551-73 (discussing how migration is a form of decolonization).
16. PATRICIA EWICK & SUSAN S. SILBEY, THE COMMON PLACE OF LAW 185 (1998).

17. See Alvaro Santos, Carving Out Policy Autonomy for Developing Countries in the World Trade Organization: The Experience of Brazil and Mexico, 52 VA.J.INT'L.L.551, 551-632 (2012) (noting that in the international trade arena, emerging economies that lack the wealth and political power to oppose the trade policies of more developed countries instead use effective lawyersing at the World Trade Organization to advance their causes).
context of nonsovereignty.
These are the MDSJs.
They are a subset of United Kingdom Overseas Territories (UKOTs) that are nonsovereign jurisdictions in the UK's "undivided realm."

While each of their constitutions gives the UK ultimate veto power over UKOT created legislation, the constitutions also provide these communities with the authority to create corporate governance rules for foreign corporations.

Significantly, MDSJs are known for their ease of incorporation, skillful deployment of corporate governance rules in service of foreign corporations, and expert use of specialized commercial courts to adjudicate business disputes.
These and other investments in corporate law have made MDSJs significant competitors to the longtime leader in corporate lawthe U.S. State of Delaware.

MDSJs rely on innovative corporate laws and legal institutions to encourage corporations and related financial services, which in turn generate revenues for the jurisdictions.[24] Fees and taxes collected from foreign corporations have significantly helped these jurisdictions become economically self-sufficient, which allows them more practical autonomy with respect to the UK.[25] By one estimate, "about a quarter of firms incorporated in foreign nations are accounted for by [MDSJs].[26] As a result of the income generated from corporations and offshore financial services, MDSJs are less reliant on the UK for budget assistance and other forms of

18. Offshore financial centers (OFCs) are jurisdictions that have an "incommensurate" reliance on financial services for nonresidents (to which reduced regulatory and tax burdens may, to be sure, contribute). BRUNER, supra note 7, at 23. These jurisdictions generally emphasize the "development of financial services capacity, including collaborative private and public sector interactions, depoliticization of finance, and efforts to generate innovative regulatory and market structures." Id. at 24.

19. Professor William Moon coined the term "Offshore Corporate Law Haven" to refer to these three jurisdictions. See generally William J. Moon, Delaware's New Competition, 114 Nw. L. REV. 1403, 1423-29 (2020) (discussing the emergence of offshore corporate law havens).
20. LOFT, supra note 8, at 4.

21. See, e.g., Tony Freyer & Andrew P. Morriss, Creating Cayman as an Offshore Financial Center: Structure & Strategy Since 1960, 45 ARIZ. ST. L.J. 1297 (2013) (discussing the constitutional structure that gave the Cayman Islands the authority to become an OFC).
22. See generally Moon, supra note 19, at 1443-50 (discussing some of the corporate governance innovations in MDSJs and related concerns for U.S. shareholders).
23. See id.; Martin W. Sybblis, Equality Offshore, 63 B.C. L. Rev. 2667, 2721-28 (2022).
24. Moon, supra note 19, at 1403-32.
Corporate Law as Decolonization

major financial assistance.[27] This minimizes the UK's day-to-day political and legal intervention into their affairs because the UK has less financial risk.[28] And, while the UK has the constitutional right to intervene in governance and lawmaking, it rarely does soleaving MDSJs virtually free to chart their own destinies.[29] The wealth generated from the offshore sectors in MDSJs also provides public goods and services for their local communities.[30]

This Article's corporate-law-as-decolonization-thesis highlights the role of economic strength as being more important than formal constitutional authority in achieving community self-determination. While political power, such as the political authority made possible through sovereignty, is a significant milestone in any community's development, it alone is an insufficient vehicle to self-determination.[31] Consider, for example, the history of race relations in urban America. In the 1980s and 1990s, after

27. The MDSJs are ineligible for budget aid from the UK because of their "high levels of income." LOFT, supra note 8, at 20-21. They are, however, eligible for "conflict, stability and security fund[ing]," especially when there is a natural disaster. PHILIP LOFT, HOUSE OF COMMONS LIBR., RSCH. BRIEFING No. 9706, BREXIT AND THE U.K.'S OVERSEAS TERRITORIES (2023), https://researchbriefings.files.parliament.uk/documents/ CBP-9592/CBP-9592.pdf [https://perma.cc/A58C-85SY]. Parts II & III of this Article further discuss the relationship between the UK and the various United Kingdom Overseas Territories (UKOTs) in the Caribbean region, including the MDSJs.

It bears noting that "[n]one of the [UKOTs] are members of the International Monetary Fund [(IMF)] or the World Bank." LOFT, supra note 27, at 18. They receive funding "from the UK or EU." Id. One source of funding for the less wealthy UKOTs is the European Development Fund (EDF) from the EU. Id. at 18-28 (discussing which UKOTs receive funds from the UK and EU). And, despite the Cayman Islands' wealthier status, it has received aid through the EDF "in the aftermath of hurricanes and natural disasters." Id. at 19. However, given the UK's withdrawal from the EU, these funds will eventually cease to be available to the UKOTs. "Under the [Brexit] Withdrawal Agreement, the [UKOTs] [will] continue to benefit from the current round of [European Development Fund], [which is] expected to run until 2024." Id.
28. See infra Part IV (discussing the relationship between the UK and economically weaker UKOTs, such as Anguilla, Montserrat, and Turks and Caicos Islands).

29. See, e.g., BRUNER, supra note 7, at 53-55 (discussing the practical aspects of the relationship between the UK and Bermuda); see generally DAVIES, supra note 4, 1-8 (discussing the legal origins and constitutional foundations of UKOTs in Bermuda and the Caribbean).
30. See infra Part V.C.2 (discussing some of the ways that MDSJs use the wealth from offshore finance to improve the lives of their residents).

31. See, e.g., GETACHEW, supra note 3, at 142-71 (discussing the postcolonial problem of neocolonialism). See also Rhoda Howard, The Full-Belly Thesis: Should Economic Rights Take Priority Over Civil and Political Rights? Evidence From Sub-Saharan Africa, HUM. RTS. Q., Nov. 1983, at 469 (discussing political rights versus economic rights).
decades of purposeful urban segregation,
cities across America celebrated the rise of Black leadership in the form of mayors.
But the fact that some cities had Black mayors did not mean the end of racial discrimination or the beginning of economic progress for Black residents.
Indeed, a change in leadership did not portend escape from oppression.
According to one scholar, in the 1990s the "Black population in these cities [relied] on other racial and ethnic groups for their economic survival."
Moreover, the election of Black mayors in "Black majority cities" was considered a "hollow prize" because of the structural "challenges in acquiring resources."
In other words, political power without economic strength is sorely limited.

Akin to the case of Black political rule in urban America, I argue that postcolonial MDSJs likely consider formal political independence a potentially vacuous achievement because of the structural inequalities built into the international economic and political arrangements.[38] The experience of some now-sovereign countries in the Caribbean region suggests as much. For example, many sovereign nations in the region have

33. See Johnnie Dee Swain, Jr., Black Mayors: Urban Decline and the Underclass, 24 J. BLACK STUD., 16, 17 (1993) (noting that in 1986, twenty-eight Black mayors represented cities of 50,000 or more in the United States).

ROBERT COLLINS, DATA CTR. RSCH., NEW ORLEANS AND THE HOLLOW PRIZE PROBLEM: STRUCTURAL LIMITS ON BLACK POLITICAL POWER 1 (2021), https://s3.amazon.com/files.datacenterresearch/systemic-inequity/papers/TDC-SIE-bob-collins-FINAL.pdf [https://perma.cc/5EWS-C2UA].

38. See infra Parts II & III (discussing why economic growth is important to former Black and Brown colonies). See also GETACHEW, supra note 3, at 107-75 (discussing the case of Black former colonies that experienced neocolonialism after they became sovereign states); MICHAEL MANLEY, UP THE DOWN ESCALATOR: DEVELOPMENT AND THE INTERNATIONAL ECONOMYA JAMIAICAN CASE STUDY (1987) (discussing the struggles of former colonies, such as Jamaica, to make economic headway given the structural inequalities built into the international economy).
Corporate Law as Decolonization
struggled with sovereign debt issues, political violence, and even political coups, highlighting the effect of structural inequalities.[39]

The leading scholarly and public policy narrative ignores the role of economic growth in the postcolonial wellbeing of some OFCs. Instead, it denigrates the success of OFCs, including MDSJs, as being the direct result of a race to the bottom.[40] From this perspective, low-to-zero taxes and lax corporate governance rules are what make these jurisdictions attractive to corporations.[41] But this account tragically oversimplifies the variety of OFCs[42] throughout the world and their range of offerings.[43] Importantly, it

39. See infra Part I (discussing the economic and political struggles of some newly independent Caribbean states in the postcolonial era). These colonies have faced tremendous economic and political difficulties internally and internationally in their attempt to reshape their governance and development landscape as newly independent states. For example, in Grenada, there was a coup in 1979. In the case of Trinidad and Tobago, there was an attempted coup in 1970. See infra Part I.C.1. And, in Jamaica, there was a physically violent and economically turbulent period in the 1970s and early 1980s during which time the country's leadership under prime minister Michael Manley experimented with democratic socialism and cultivated a close relationship with Cuba's Fidel Castro. See infra Part I.B.2 (discussing the efforts on the part of the 1970s socialist Jamaican government to create a more egalitarian society on the island).
40. See Moon, supra note 19, at 1413-16 (discussing the race to the bottom narrative, especially with respect to lower taxes and more flexible legislation).

41. See GABRIEL ZUCMAN, THE HIDDEN WEALTH OF NATIONS: THE SCOURGE OF TAX HAVENS (Teresa Lavender Fagan trans., Univ. of Chi. Press 2015) (2013); Gabriel Zucman & Gus Wezerek, Opinion, This Is Tax Evasion, Plain and Simple, N.Y. REV. 1683, 1710 n.126 (2021) (discussing the attraction of the British Virgin Islands to Chinese closely held companies); Moon, supra note 19, at 1410 n.33 (2020) (discussing the Cayman Islands' reputation for managing hedge fund assets). The prevailing account also disregards the postcolonial autonomy and self-determination interests that drive some OFCs, such as MDSJs, to strategically invest in their corporate governance laws as one vehicle for meaningful self-determination.
This Article seeks to supplement the dominant discourse regarding OFCs and thereby provide a more complete picture of their social, legal, and economic impact on various communities.

This Article is the first in legal scholarship to make the connection between corporate governance laws and the decolonization experience of certain colonies.[47] It contributes to the important scholarly and policy discourse on international tax, the competition for corporate charters, race and global inequality, the legacies of colonialism, the postcolonial pursuit of self-determination, law and development, law and political economy, and comparative law.[48] It also provides much needed nuance to the current

Sybblis, Regulatory Competition and State Capacity, 13 WM. & MARY BUS. L. REV. 189, 233-60 (2021) (discussing how state capacity developed in the colonial period may have impacted offshore development in the postcolonial era); see also ORLANDO PATTerson, THE CONFOUNDING ISLAND: JAMAICA AND THE POSTCOLONIAL PREDICAMENT 21-119 (2019) (explaining how a country's colonial socio-history can impact its postcolonial development trajectory); Kenneth L. Sokoloff & Stanley L. Engerman, History Lessons: Institutions, Factor Endowments, and Paths of Development in the New World, 14 J. ECON. PERSPS. 217, 223-32 (2000) (discussing the relationship between institutions and the "inequality across New World economies").

45. To the extent that on the booksi.e., by virtue of their constitutionsultimate legislative authority rests in the UK Parliament and not in the local legislatures of these jurisdictions, they are arguably not as free as they could be. See generally DAVIES, supra note 4, 136-229 (discussing the constitutions of UKOTs in the Caribbean). But, given the social and economic context discussed in Part II, they have come a far wayand arguably further along in their path to self-determination than other former colonies in the Caribbean region.

REV. 867, 896-935 (discussing the concept of CEI and its influence on legal reform); Sybblis, supra note 44, 244-61 (discussing the relationship between colonialism, "institutional learning," and the development of successful postcolonial OFCs).

48. See, e.g., Moon, supra note 19, 1423-29 (discussing the global competitiveness of Bermuda, the British Virgin Islands, and the Cayman Islands); BRUNER, supra note 7, at 41-191 (discussing the rise of powerful small OFCs); TSILLY DAGAN, INTERNATIONAL
Corporate Law as Decolonization

debate over corporate profit shifting and the related erosion of the tax bases in non-offshore jurisdictions by including the lives, histories, and aspirations of Black and Brown communities in former colonies. These communities are too frequently overlooked and disregarded in international law and policy circles.[49] And, while this Article does not seek to make a claim for reparations for Black and Brown postcolonial OFCs, it suggests that wealthy countries in the Global North consider solutions to the tax evasion and "financial opacity"[50] that minimize the harm to vulnerable postcolonial jurisdictions that facilitate offshore business law and offshore finance.[51] In short, this Article complicates the dominant corporate law imperialism perspective and introduces a corporate law as decolonization perspective to the legal and policy discourse on OFCs.

The remainder of this Article is organized in five parts. Part I discusses the ways commentators have conceptualized the process and goals of decolonization. B. The Anticipated Life After Decolonization

Political independence is typically a time of great jubilation.[76] Consider the case of the former British colony of Rhodesia, which became the sovereign nation of Zimbabwe[77] at midnight on April 18, 1980.[78] Leaders from across the world gathered in the Rufaro football stadium in Harare, including Prince Charles (now King Charles III),[79] and the music of legendary reggae musician Bob Marley filled the air. The opening lyrics of Marley's song, titled "Zimbabwe" as written for the new nation,[80]aignantly stated: "Every man got a right to decide his own destiny."[81] It was this sense of immense possibility for the future, which the people of Zimbabwe would now be responsible for charting for themselves, that imbued the crowd in the stadium with euphoria.[82] While it is difficult to quantify or describe what approximately 40,000 people in Harare were feeling and thinking in that moment, three aspects of independence were likely on their minds: (1) the power to govern freely; (2) the ability to build a more inclusive society; and (3) the right to an international voice.[83]

In the case of Britain's former colonies,[87] the Governor's approval for legal reform was no longer required and legislative autonomy was completely vested in an elected parliament in each country.[88] The intent was to create productive trading arrangements with wealthier nations.[89] Indeed, the goal for many former colonies was to organize domestic institutions and make their own laws to ensure that their own national interests, and not the interests of their former ruler, were being prioritized.[90] Political independence "was [arguably] the achievement of mass nationalism."[91] And, for those jurisdictions that sought to gain greater control of their natural resources and to capitalize on new economic opportunities, political independence meant less European dominance of the domestic sector.[92]

2. More Inclusive Societies

An implicit expectation of colonized people was that decolonization would bring demographic changes to their new country, and with them, social and economic opportunities for previously excluded communities.[96] Specifically, reduced European immigration to the country suggested that non-European residents would have greater opportunities for economic and social progresswhich were withheld under the colonial regime.[97] In the case of Jamaica, the largest English-speaking island colony in the Caribbean,[98] the government of the 1970s pursued a democratic socialist agenda as a way of promoting economic growth and addressing the social harms faced by African Jamaican people during the colonial period.[99]

For example, the Jamaican government engaged in outreach to the Rastafarian communitya religious group whose faith is linked to their African heritageand deployed rhetoric that signaled a desire for inclusive economic and social policies pertaining to African Jamaican people.[100] Political scientists Evelyn Stephens and John D. 3. An International Voice

Beyond domestic concerns, a third expectation on the part of postcolonial communities was that the new state would be able to engage the international community without an intermediaryan ability that epitomizes sovereignty.[107] The United Nations (UN) was expected to be the prime forum from which these countries could pursue their interests.[108] According to political scientist Adom Getachew, "[e]mpire comes to an end when formerly excluded colonies enter international society as full members, and central to this inclusion is the universalization of the nation-state as the accepted institutional form of self-determination."[109]

C. The Realist View of Decolonization

Decolonized communities in the Global South hoped that the UN would become more than a place for theoretical debates among sovereign states.[113] They wanted it to be the venue for the remaking of the postcolonial world order.[114] But this was not to be the case.[115] Postcolonial realist leaders from Black and Brown countries quickly discerned that their [s]tates would be nominally free, and yet their economic dependence on particular states or their vulnerability to international trade and finance created the conditions in which political domination could be exercised by other means.[116] Significantly, without a change in the international power structure that relegated these countries to the global periphery, they had little ability to make meaningful progress.[117]

Three features of the landscape of postcolonial possibilities indicated that the path to prosperity and self-determination would be a rocky one with many hurdles.[118] First, the various models of economic development proposed would ultimately fail. Second, the UN would not be the avenue for reform of the international economic order. Third, law and neoliberal economic development would be the path dictated to them by wealthy Western nations.[119]

1. Challenge #1: The Economy

As countries in the global south entered the postcolonial era, they were faced with diverse economic challenges.[120] The decades following the heights of British decolonization (from approximately from the 1960s to 1980s)[121] were known for famine and sovereign debt issues[122] as well as political violence and social turmoil in some places.[123] The latter two features permeated some of the larger island nations in the British Caribbean. For example, Trinidad and Tobago experienced an attempted coup in 1970,[124] Grenada experienced a completed coup in 1979,[125] and Jamaica was riddled with political violence in the 1970s and early 1980s.[126]

A consistent theme ran throughout these events: economic turmoil on each island.[127] The upheaval in Jamaica in the late 1970s under the Michael Manley government was in large part because of the economic hardships experienced by the population.[128] The revolutions in Trinidad and Tobago and Grenada were also in part because of economic strife in the young countries.[129] In the postcolonial period, newly sovereign states struggled to create economies that sufficiently and evenly lifted all segments of their societies.[130]

Nobel laureate Sir Arthur Lewis.
Professor Lewis had a clear sense of the problem of underdevelopment in the tropics, including the Caribbean.
The problem, in his view, was not so much colonial domination as agricultural productivity.
According to Lewis, developing countries needed an "agricultural revolution."
As he saw it, this was an economic problem not a political one.
Both sufficient food and raw materials were needed to support an industrial sector that could help to drive the economy.
Consequently, the optimal approach was an economic policy that "simultaneously revolutionized agriculture to increase food production and initiated processes of industrialization."
Curiously, Professor Lewis did not indicate a role for international organizations or power structures in bolstering the efforts of postcolonial developing jurisdictions.

3. Challenge #3: Neoliberal Economics

Sovereignty without economic strength proved to be a problem for newly independent states of the Global South in the decades of the 1980s and 1990s.[156] The NIEO movement was swiftly displaced by the neoliberal economic policies emanating from Washington, DC.[157] For those former colonies that had to borrow money to meet their needs, the structural adjustment programs of the IMF led to major "devaluation of [currencies]; major cuts in public expenditures, especially in the wages of public sector workers; and the privatization of state assets."[158] Despite the mandatory policy reforms that came with IMF loans, the developing nations that should have benefited from financial assistance suffered under crushing austerity.[159]

Notably, newly independent states from the global south did not get a seat at the international table as equals to their former colonizers.[160] Instead, the UNwhere they anticipated the center of international economic policymaking would bewas dislodged by other prominent venues.[161]

In short, decolonization without economic growth and prosperitywhether as a nation or postcolonial individual<sup>164</sup>is incomplete at best and illusory at worst.<sup>165</sup> Importantly, once decolonization is seen as having an inextricable economic component, the type of strategies deployed by postcolonial nations to achieve this aspect will be reflected in their development choices.<sup>166</sup> It is worthwhile to understand how some former colonies have sought to achieve self-determination in the wake of the economic struggles that tend to accompany these jurisdictions in the postcolonial era.<sup>167</sup> In Part II, I show how a set of OFCs in the Commonwealth Caribbean have invested in corporate law as a way of achieving economic growth and, consequently, some of the promised fruits of decolonization.<sup>168</sup>

II. CORPORATE LAW AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT

Institutions are considered essential for economic development.[169] Legal scholars argue that the architecture and functioning of legal institutions in developing countries are vital to those countries' potential for prosperity.[170] According to this theory, institutions are crucial to development because of "the incentives they create [for actors] to engage in either socially productive or socially unproductive activities."[171] On a meta level, early theorists conceptualized development as a process"a series of successive stages of economic growth through which all countries must pass."[172] Consequently, these theorists thought it feasible to expedite the process of economic development in poor countries by copying and implementing institutionsincluding legal institutionsfrom wealthy countries.[173] Given the economic success of Western nations, adopting their laws was seen as a way to provide certainty and efficiency in the commercial affairs and economic development aspirations of poorer jurisdictions.[174]

International finance institutions (IFIs), such as the World Bank, have embraced this theoretical connection between legal institutions and economic development.[175] For example, for more than a decade, the World Bank actively encouraged developing countries to adopt economic growth-promoting legal reforms.[176] These reforms included several corporate and

Corporations are important contributors to economic growth.[181] They effectively [channel] funds from the ultimate savers in a society to enterprises that will invest those funds in productive uses.[182] But this is only possible because of the legal rules that govern the corporation and its use of the capital.[183] As corporate law scholar Katharina Pistor artfully explains, capital and law are intricately intertwined.[184] Capital ultimately ows its capacity to create wealth to the modules of a legal code that is backed by state power.[185]

Several smaller former colonies of the United Kingdom have similarly sought the use of corporate law as a vehicle for economic prosperityand (as described below) a form of decolonization.[192] These include, but are not limited to, the islands of Antigua, Anguilla, Barbados, Bermuda, the Cayman Islands, Hong Kong, Montserrat, Turks and Caicos, and the British Virgin Islands.[193] These countries have been referred to as tax havens.[194] Significantly, three British postcolonial islands have had tremendous success attracting foreign corporationsa significant economic benefitwithout being sovereign countries.[195] They are Bermuda, the British Virgin Islands, and the Cayman Islands: the MDSJs.[196] They have also developed into attractive venues for corporations and dispute resolution, making them rivals to Delaware.[197]

They have developed a similar development model to that which has been exemplified in Delaware and marketed by scholars and IFIs.[199] They utilize legal rules and institutions as a means of facilitating commercial activities which have in turn promoted economic growth.[200] Importantly, scholars argue that the attractiveness of MDSJs is not limited to their low or zero corporate tax rates.[201] Indeed, [a] growing body of evidence concerning jurisdictions generally deemed tax havens suggests that they cannot effectively attract mobile capital on the basis of their tax regimes alone.[202] Below, I provide examples of three MDSJsBermuda, the British Virgin Islands, and the Cayman Islandsthat have been extraordinarily successful in attracting capital, at least in part, because of their corporate law regimes.
B. Examples From Market Dominant Small Jurisdictions

The approach of the MDSJs has been to provide flexible and attractive corporate laws for corporationslike Delaware's strategy.[203] "In recent years, the British Virgin Islands, for example, has derived over half of its government revenue from incorporation-related fees."[204] Bermuda derived 6.3 percent of its revenue from incorporation fees between 2016 and 2017.[205] The Cayman Islands gained 12.8 percent during this same period.[206] Further, the foreign corporations that incorporate in these jurisdictions "help create jobs in the local economy."[207] To achieve these outcomes, among a variety of strategies, local policymakers and business leaders have: (1)

1. Constant Legal Innovation
a. Bermuda

Bermuda's early colonial economy was based on a combination of agriculture, shipbuilding, and tourism.[209] It was not until the mid-1940s that Bermudians began to invest in offshore financial services.[210] Today, among OFCs, Bermuda is known as one of the largest reinsurance centers in the world, as well as a market leader where it concerns "captive insurance domicile."[211] Offshore financial services and tourism together are the cornerstone of Bermuda's modern-day economy.[212] By all accounts the island is economically successful.[213] In 2016, Bermuda had "the fourth highest per capita income in the world, about 70 percent higher than that of the USa position achieved principally through services, estimated to account for over 93 percent of [gross domestic product (GDP)] in 2015."[214]

Unlike the Cayman Islands, which entered the corporations race in the 1960s,[227] the British Virgin Islands passed its International Business Companies Ordinance in 1984almost two decades later.[228] But the jurisdiction has fast become an attractive OFC because it allows corporations seeking to incorporate the ability to opt out of historically standard default corporate governance rules in the United States, including Delaware.[229] Further, to ensure that the British Virgin Islands' corporate governance rules remain current and competitive, "a group of prominent private sector lawyers serving on the Financial Services Commission provide specific input relating to amendments on the British Virgin Islands' Companies Act (BVI's corporate law statute).[230] For example, "as recently as June 2018, the Commission advised the cabinet of the British Virgin Islands to revise the Companies Act by lowering penalties for corporate noncompliance."[231]
c. Cayman Islands

The Cayman Islands became a colony of Britain in 1670. It was not the typical sugar colony and was administered by Britain from Jamaica for almost three hundred years.[232] The jurisdiction held such a subordinate status among British colonies that it was known as a colony of a colony.[233] Turtle fishing and boat building comprised its early economy.[234] Today, the Cayman Islands is well known for its expertise for hedge funds.[235] But it is also known for being a key jurisdiction for captive insurance companies, yacht registrations, special purpose vehicles, and international banking.[236]

The jurisdiction's legal innovations around corporate law began with its constitution.[237] At a meta-constitutional level, the Cayman Islands was committed to creating sufficient autonomy to allow for an economic growth enabling corporate law regime.[238] Given that the Cayman Islands was governed from Jamaica for much of its colonial period, when Jamaica sought and achieved political independence, it was necessary for Caymanians to collaborate with Britain to adopt a new constitution that would enable adequate self-governance. The real aim of this self-governance was to facilitate the development of the legal infrastructure that was necessary to attract incorporations without relying on Jamaican law.[239]

The Cayman Islands' new constitutional arrangement with Britain allowed it to produce its very own Companies Law in 1960.[240] To stay competitive with other jurisdictions, "the Cayman Islands has updated its Companies Law at least fifty-eight times."[241] More recently, Applebyan international law firm operating in the Cayman Islands and other OFCs[242]has highlighted the jurisdiction's continued corporate law innovations.[243] For example, the law firm notes that Cayman Islands has: (1) created "framework legislation regulating virtual asset service providers;"[244] (2) "established a technology park ... to allow technology companies to benefit from specific advantages, including zero taxes and fast tracked work permit applications for relocating employees;"[245] and (3) provide a range of flexible

2. Collaboration With the Private Sector

Much like Delaware,[247] MDSJs are known for their close interaction with the private sector, including foreign law firms that help to draft local legislation.[248] Some scholars refer to this relationship as a "collaborative policy-making process."[249] In the Cayman Islands, this type of collaboration "enabled it to strike the balance necessary to innovate and grow while screening out problematic individuals, firms, and lines of business."[250] Other scholars suggest that successful jurisdictions, such as Bermuda, actively maintain a delicate balancing actensuring "close collaboration with and robust oversight of the financial professional community."[251]

Perhaps the tension that underpins the MDSJs' collaboration with the private sector is revealed in the substance of the corporate laws they produce.[252] Reasonable minds could disagree over whether the innovations coming out of these jurisdictions reflect straightforward and efficient regulatory competition or a race to the bottomthat is, a proliferation of lax legislation that benefits corporate managers and directors.[253] Three areas of

While derivative suits are designed to enable shareholders to bring lawsuits against the individuals who are tasked with the day-to-day running of the corporation for mismanagement, they are more difficult to undertake in MDSJs.[255] For example, "[i]n the British Virgin Islands, shareholders must first seek permission from the court prior to bringing a derivative suit."[256] The same is true in the Cayman Islands.[257] This barrier to redress could be a meaningful deterrent to shareholders who are justified in their claims against corporate officers and managers.[258]

Where it concerns the traditional United States shareholders' rights to inspect corporate records to learn more about the corporation's daily operations, MDSJs tend to provide no such access.[259] Indeed, "[b]ooks and records inspections are uniformly forbidden under the laws of [MDSJs].[260] And, perhaps most surprising, some MDSJs allow corporations that register in their jurisdiction to "opt out of fiduciary duties" to shareholders.[261] Bermuda is one such jurisdiction that allows corporations to elect this option, thereby preventing "fiduciary duty claims against directors and officers except in events of fraud or dishonesty."[262]

Overall, the more permissive corporate governance rules of the MDSJs naturally raise questions about the nature of shareholder rights.[263] But they could also be considered a more efficient way of managing the corporation by restricting the types of disputes that the entity must engage with.[264] In either

3. Specialized Commercial Courts

Over the past decade and a half, MDSJs have invested in developing business courts to address the disputes that emerge from their international business sector.[266] Much like Delaware's Court of Chancery, these jurisdictions are seeking to complement their incorporations business with dispute resolution fora.[267] They have not only built physical facilities for these specialized business courts but have also ensured that they are staffed with distinguished judges who are corporate and commercial law experts.[268] Professor Moon suggests that "[t]he quasi-public nature of offshore judicial proceedings, which look a lot like modern commercial arbitration, helps these jurisdictions compete in the global corporate law market."[269]

These specialized commercial courts in MDSJs are part of what is becoming "the adjudication business."[270] According to Professor Pamela Bookman, jurisdictions are "establishing international commercial courts: English-language-friendly domestic courts specializing in international commercial disputes."[271] The jury is still out, but if there is concern that MDSJs are promoting lax rules, the development of specialized commercial courts across a range of jurisdictions should assuage this concern.[272] It is theorized that the competition among these courts will produce a "race to the top' for tribunals to develop the best, most efficient procedures to resolve disputes."[273]
III. CORPORATE LAW AND DECOLONIZATION
The argument that corporate law is a pathway to decolonization is highly contextual. It expands in part upon insights from the law, institutions,

My thesis is that, through the tangible benefits of being a territory of a larger and wealthier nation and the practical autonomy that is gained from economic success, MDSJs have access to some of the fruits of decolonization that other jurisdictions that are similarly situated (in terms of size and colonial history) do not.

A key distinction between the politically independent states of the Caribbean region and the remaining UKOTs is that, for the latter, there is still "the reservation of responsibility for certain affairs to the governor," whose office represents the English Crown.[283] While the "[UK] government and Parliament retains the power to intervene, amend constitutions, and to create law" in each UKOT, the amount of authority that is retained largely depends on the territory. In large part, the governor "retains responsibility for external affairs, [defense] and internal security (such as the police and judiciary).[284] These powers allow the governor to act without the permission of the UKOT's local legislature.[285] Even where the UK and its governors have the power to intervene in specific areas of governance, they are not eager to use their powers.[286] Instead, they are inclined to build consensus with local legislators.[287]

The strategy is to maintain a healthy working relationship with the "democratically elected governments" of the UKOTs.[288] This strategy is especially useful to the UK and its governors "when [UK]OTs are no longer in receipt of UK government funding."[289] Financial assistance generally allows for more power on the part of the provider because it comes with conditions.[290] Additionally, some UK-appointed governors are new to the job

There is a direct relationship between the degree of governance oversight by the UK and the economic conditions of the colony.[293] Without economic success in a colony, meaningful constitutional autonomy is illusory.[294] For example, when the former sugar-producing colonies were no longer profitable, Britain made it clear that any assistance provided to these territories would come with oversight.[295] Sadly, developing countriesprimarily in the Global Southstill bear the burden of oversight from wealthy nations and former colonial empires in large part because they lack the resources to sustain themselves.[296] In this regard, there are practical limitations to what sovereignty can deliver for some jurisdictions.[297]

Corporate Law as Decolonization
B. Decolonization and Dependency

The experience of the MDSJs suggests that economic success and minimal dependence on the UK could be a gateway to practical sovereignty.[298] Below, I explain how economic development in each MDSJ, beginning with Bermuda, has led to increased practical sovereignty. I also highlight where incidents of corruption in places such as the British Virgin Islands and the Cayman Islands have endangered this autonomy.
1. Bermuda

Bermuda's economic success has contributed to its legal and political autonomy, even while it remains a UKOT.[299] Professor Bruner suggests that the relationship between Bermuda and the UK is "a mutually beneficial one."[300] On the one hand, Bermuda (1) gets national security protections, (2) receives some aid from the UK[301] and the European Union (EU) as a result of Bermuda's status as a UKOT,[302] and (3) benefits reputationallyin terms of its global statusfrom its connection to the UK.[303] On the other hand, the UK benefits from the offshore financial services provided by Bermuda (as well as

One persistent argument to remain a UKOT is tied to Bermuda's economic future. Bermuda's ability to craft corporate and commercial legislation, such as the Exempted Companies Act of 1950 which had material benefits for the larger society, could be interpreted as one version of postcolonial sovereignty for the Bermudian people.[311] According to at least one scholar, there are Black Bermudian people who "do not now see the need for political independence in order to enhance their material and social well-being."[312] Essentially, these Bermudians are not persuaded of the benefits of formal independence. Writing in the late 1980s, not long before a referendum on independence, Professor Ahiakpor noted:

[F]or all practical purposes, [Bermudians have] been their own masters since the 1970s, being able to enact legislation and run the country under a Governor who hardly acts without consultation with the Premier and an advisory council composed of Bermudians. Until they see significant positive contributions to their lives from political independence, they are content with the present constitutional arrangement.[313]

With respect to the exercise of its reserved powers, the UK has actively considered direct rule in the British Virgin Islands because of alleged corruption in the local government.[318] "In April 2022, [the British Virgin Islands] Premier Andrew Fahie was arrested in the United States on charges relating to drug[] trafficking and money laundering."[319] According to a Commission of Inquiry in 2022, the British Virgin Islands government ignored "principles ... of openness, transparency and the rule of law."[320] Ultimately, the UK decided that direct rule would not be imposed and "accepted a proposal of the [British Virgin Islands] Government for the locally elected Government to introduce the recommended reforms."[321]

3. Cayman Islands

Similar to Bermuda and the British Virgin Islands, the Cayman Islands' legislature is responsible for local lawmaking.[326] The governor has the power, after consulting with the premier, to assent to laws "that have not been introduced to the Legislative Assembly or those that are unlikely to pass."[327] Further, the governor must provide assent to any bill coming from the Legislative Assembly before it can become law.[328] The "[UK] Parliament and Privy council" have the power to make laws for the Cayman Islands notwithstanding the opinion of the Legislative Assembly or Premier.[329] Also, as in the case of the British Virgin Islands, the governor can delegate authority to the premier or another minister of government for limited external affairs activities.[330] Importantly, there have been no recent discussions of the imposition of direct rule in the Cayman Islands by the UK.[331]

In summary, the ability to chart its own future in the context of a subordinate relationship with the UK facilitates some of the aspirations of decolonization as both a process and an end goal. As a process, there is some degree of separation between the former colony (now UKOT) and the former colonial ruler. The UKOT can make policy for itself and, so long as it is economically independent and not reliant on the UK for financial assistance, it is more or less left to its own goals.[335] As an end goal, an economically successful UKOT can provide for a high standard of living for its population and is not beholden to IFIs, as the sovereign developing former colonies in the Caribbean have been in the past.[336] Significantly, in the case of MDSJs of English legal origin, the reputational support of the former colonial ruler strengthens its stature on the world stagethereby increasing its likelihood of attracting investors and would-be incorporsators.[337]
IV. LIMITATIONS TO THE DECOLONIZATION AND CORPORATE LAW THESIS

Below, I argue that self-determination in the postcolonial era may prove elusive for jurisdictions that lack state capacity or that struggle to curb corruption, even if those jurisdictions are overseas territories and attempt to use corporate law as a means of achieving economic success.
A. State Capacity Matters

A former colony or overseas territory that has limited state capacity will be unlikely to build the legal infrastructure (for example, corporate governance rules, specialized courts, regulatory agencies) to attract foreign corporations and investors.[339] This type of jurisdiction may find the process of trying to attract and retain foreign corporations to be frustrating because it does not have the bureaucratic depth and resources to implement its regulations.[340]

On paper, Montserrat has the greatest autonomy of all the UKOTs, with the office of the governor possessing relatively less power over the internal management of the jurisdiction.[372] The Assembly of Montserrat is primarily responsible for making laws for the jurisdiction,[373] with a lawmaking body composed of a legislative assembly, premier, and [three] ministers of government.[374] While the UK-appointed governor cannot make laws for Montserrat without the local legislator playing a role in the process,[375] "the Crown reserves the right, with the advice of the Privy Council, to make laws for Montserrat."[376]

The governor, however, retains power over Montserrat's international financial services operations.[377] This constitutional limitation on the island's autonomy stems from a history of financial services scandals and immense dependence on the UK in the wake of the volcanic eruption in the late 1990s.[378] Greater economic reliance on the UK came with a reduction in internal autonomy, since the UK wanted more oversight over the use of its funds.[379]

The UK subsequently restored the government in 2011, and in 2012, new elections ushered in a new House of Assembly.[388] Based on the history of corruption in Turks and Caicos' government, "[t]he island's constitution is seen as containing more reserved powers for the Governor than other [UKOTs], allowing them to act without the consent of the legislature more widely."[389] A recent movement to increase the autonomy of the local officials failed. For Turks and Caicos, corruption in governance has significantly weakened the ability of local elected officials to manage the affairs of the society. Further, this jurisdiction's experience with corruption highlights the delicate balance that the UKOTs face when seeking to maintain the national security and reputational benefits of a close relationship with the UK on the one hand while achieving self-determination on the other hand.
V. IMPLICATIONS

The success and competitiveness of MDSJs have brought to light important sociological features regarding the corporations and corporate governance regimes in these jurisdictions.[391] The prevailing media narrative that highlights the nefarious aspects of OFCssuch as money laundering, terrorism financing, tax evasion, and profit shifting[392]has overshadowed the various types of offshore jurisdictions, caricatured the people who live in these places, and ignored their histories.[393] Indeed, the people who live in

There are at least three implications of the corporate-law-as-decolonization thesis for the communities in postcolonial OFCs, especially MDSJs. First, it connects corporate law to national identity and freedom in these jurisdictions. Second, it highlights the vulnerability and limited choices available to what may be perceived as market dominant jurisdictions.[395] Third, it suggests that the international community make continual efforts to find creative ways of ensuring that former colonies achieve justice and fairness in the postcolonial era.
A. Corporate Law, Identity, and Freedom

The ability of MDSJs to effectively compete with Delaware for corporations suggests a deep commitment to their offshore financial and corporate law sectors.[396] This commitment is arguably driven by an end goal: meaningful decolonizationeven while remaining an UKOT.[397] In the process of attaining postcolonial freedom, these jurisdictions have developed a national identity associated with offshore finance and corporate law serves.[398] The theory is that a community's visible commitmentssuch as where they spend their valuable tax revenues and build institutionsprovides information about the type of programs and activities with which they identify.[399] For example, an island nation that invests in hospitality services provides financial support for hotels and restaurants and actively promotes tourism, which may then be appropriately considered a place for

While commentators readily assume that corporate and individual greed are the only drivers in the world of offshore finance and offshore corporate law, the story is much more complicated.[402] Bound up in what appears at first glance to be a purely economic affair is a deeper sociopolitical phenomenon.[403] The act of creating corporate governance rules that facilitate wealth and enable greater autonomy is intertwined with the colonial and slave histories of the MDSJs and larger Caribbean region.[404] For example, in the early 1990s there was pride among British Virgin Islanders regarding the writing of their own "International Business Companies Ordinance."[405] This law made it feasible for foreign corporations to incorporate in the British Virgin Islands without paying local income tax.[406] While the law proved to be "one of the most important pieces of legislation for the economic prosperity of the territory ever introduced" during that time period, it was also significant to the British Virgin Islanders because it was a law they wrote themselves.[407] In this regard, it placed British Virgin Islanders in charge of their own destinies and ability for self-determination even though they are very much a UKOT.[408]

There is an obvious challenge to the practical sovereignty view of decolonization as it relates to MDSJs: what some commentators may perceive as practical autonomy could be viewed by others as subordination.[409] Scholars who write about power have suggested that its most effective use occurs when the dominated are not aware of being dominated.[410] Arguably, jurisdictions such as the MDSJs are subservient to capital markets and to investors, even if they only focus on their jurisdictions' sense of empowerment and self-determination.[411] Essentially, MDSJs are dependent on capital from wealthy corporations and on investors who might prove especially sensitive to cycles in the market or to negative news about these offshore jurisdictions.[412]

Further, there is the relentless pressure from the members of the international community, such as the OECD and the EU, to reform the legal standards and institutions in OFCs to address "onshore" jurisdictions' concerns about tax evasion and other economic crimes.[413] For example, the EU has at some point listed Anguilla, Bermuda, the British Virgin Islands, the Cayman Islands, Montserrat, and the Turks and Caicos Islands as "non-cooperative jurisdictions" with regard to "international tax standards."[414]

Notwithstanding this reality, for the MDSJs, the pathway to at least some of the fruits of decolonization may be on balance the better option. The choice is ultimately between certain subordination as a sovereign, small former colony and a contingent subordination based on the international political economy of the offshore finance landscape.[415] The matter of agency tips the choice in favor of UKOT status. For the MDSJs, if they do their part and maintain a well-functioning, transparent (that is, corruption-free), and effective offshore financial infrastructure, it gives them tremendous standing in the world of international finance[416] and gives the UK less reason to be concerned about their increased dependency.[417]
B. Regarding Vulnerability and Decolonization

If we conceive of offshore finance as a vehicle to minimize the vulnerability of postcolonial communities, a more humane response should undergird the work of the United States, OECD, and the EU in addressing the problems of tax evasion, profit shifting, and base erosion.
With respect to the vulnerability thesis, Professor Fineman suggests that it is the state's responsibility to facilitate the resilience and flourishing of its population.
In the international sphere, the responsibility to ensure the resilience and flourishing of people in poorer jurisdictions arguably extends to an international network of actors.

In 2015, the European Union's Economic and Financial Affairs (ECOFIN) Council developed the policy that OFCs should show evidence that entities incorporated in their jurisdiction are doing meaningful business, or the jurisdiction would be "placed on a list of non-cooperative jurisdictions."[430] This policy requires OFCs to create and implement "economic substance legislation."[431] The goal is to ensure that entities are engaged in "real economic activity" and aren't merely incorporating to benefit from the tax (or even corporate governance) regime. [5] headquarters business; [6] holding company business; [7] insurance business; [8] intellectual property business; or [9] shipping business."432

Entities engaged in these businesses can provide evidence of their engagement. For example, they can show that they are: (1) managing commercial activities from the jurisdiction; (2) undertaking of "incomegenerating activities in the jurisdiction;" and (3) employing an appropriate number of employees in the jurisdiction.[433] To the extent that MDSJs can nudge investors to direct capital to industries that produce goods for export and generate enduring employment, this may be a good tool for sustained economic development in these jurisdictions. It may also provide opportunities for new commercial activities within these jurisdictions.

Ultimately, the EU's economic substance policy toward OFCs could provide an institutional framework that mitigates some of the vulnerabilities of small jurisdictions. To the extent that MDSJs choose to adopt this approach, it could provide them with further economic independence. The offshore model that encourages incorporations without meaningful capital investments could therefore be seen as one step in a "multi-step development" model whereby early offshore financial legislation is reformed to facilitate new types of investmentsincluding in the technological space.[434] The legal infrastructure and expertise developed in the offshore finance arena could translate into expertise that could underpin venture capitalists looking to develop technology hubs throughout the Caribbean.[435] Current examples of how meaningful capital investments can transform OFCs that are committed to the sector can be seen in the Cayman Islands and in Bermuda.[436]

The goal is to use the skills and expertise available in the tourism and financial services sector to complement healthcare expertise on the island and provide high quality healthcare to tourists at a lower cost than in the United States.
Foreign investment in this sector could prove invaluable and create an entirely new pillar of the island's economy.
In Bermuda, the political leadership recognizes that one of the island's key strengths is legislation.
In a recent interview, the Premier of Bermuda confidently noted that the territory is skilled at making and implementing efficient regulation.
Building on this skillset, Bermudians are now aiming to swiftly create regulations in other areas that could be beneficial to the population.

C. Regarding the Problem of Fairness and Inequality

A third implication of the corporate law as decolonization thesis is that the predominantly Black postcolonial countries and territories, including those associated with the former British empire, have been left to find a narrow and highly contingent path to self-determination.[445]
1. Fairness

The promise of freedom and self-determination after centuries of colonial domination has been illusory.[446] Anticolonial nationalist leaders such as Michael Manley (Jamaica), Eric Williams (Trinidad and Tobago), and Kwame Nkrumah (Ghana) harshly critiqued the struggles of Third World countries at the hands of former empires as nothing short of neocolonialism.[447] While some scholars from the global south have

451. Professor Vanessa Ogle explains: European rule during the 1950s and 1960s was often accompanied by a liquidation and removal of European assets. Many Europeans, moreover, held deep-seated racist convictions about the absence of business acumen among native populations and simply could not imagine economic life continuing in regular form after independence. Following decolonization, many low-income countries therefore desperately needed foreign capital to start a process of industrialization and growth promotion .... These theories fail to appreciate the stratified nature of the global economy and, consequently, the limitations of domestic legal reform in former colonies in the face of the raw power emanating from wealthy nations and former colonial rulers.
For example, following the recommendations of wealthy Western nations in the postcolonial era has not been a winning strategy.

While the state of Delaware has maintained itself and its economy on its incorporations and corporate law franchise, Black countries and territories in the global south that have undertaken similar paths have been demonized and treated as criminal suspectsas aiding tax evasion, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism.

Consequently, while it would be academically satisfying to suggest that corporate law, if implemented and practiced appropriately, could broadly facilitate the hopes and dreams of postcolonial nations, it would be difficult to prove. Corporate law (and commercial law more broadly), as outlined herein, can be immensely useful for promoting economic growth and thereby for facilitating forms of self-determination in specific contexts.[457] This Article suggests that the Black postcolonial jurisdictions that have had the best chance at achieving self-determination through the "law-growth nexus"[458]

For sovereign former colonies, this arrangement is not as feasible because they have already legally and politically separated themselves from their former colonial rulers.[461] And for some "partially independent territories,"[462] their capacity limitations and institutional weaknesses make it difficult to deploy the sophisticated legal rules associated with competitive jurisdictions, such as Delaware, Bermuda, and the Cayman Islands.[463]

While inequality is relevant to discussions of economic development, this Article's focus is on the practical autonomy that MDSJs enjoy with respect to their former colonial controllers.[470] Two points bear noting. First, for small jurisdictions like Bermuda, the Cayman Islands, and the British Virgin Islands to ensure inclusive economic development, they must first have wealth to redistribute. Regardless of one's assessment of offshore financial services, the wealth generated from this sector provides a source of income that MDSJs can distribute throughout their societies.[471] Second, there is reason to believe that governments and private sector organizations in MDSJs are making attempts to provide for the overall welfare of their populations and include a cross section of Bermudians in the offshore sector.[472] For example, in the case of Bermuda's dominant insurance and reinsurance sector, the Island's Premier noted that major international law firms and auditing firms are "employing and training Bermudians" and that the "pipeline of local talent" that supports the sector is growing.[473] Further,

In short, while the income from the offshore sector may not be evenly distributed throughout the societies in MDSJs, these jurisdictions are certainly economically and, where it concerns public goods delivery, arguably better than they would have been without the revenue generated from offshore corporate law activities. For example, in 2017, the British Virgin Islands had a maternal mortality ratio of zero deaths per 100[.]000 live births.

Due to the wealth gained through offshore corporate law and financial activities, they have the economic capacity to address the social and economic needs of their societiesshould they desiremore than some independent nations.
CONCLUSION

This Article argues that corporate law has quietly provided a path to decolonization for a set of postcolonial jurisdictions, even as these jurisdictions remain subsovereign territories of their former colonial controller. In the decolonization literature, economic growth, and ultimately economic self-reliance, is considered crucial for meaningful decolonization.[483] In jurisdictions such as Bermuda, the British Virgin Islands, and the Cayman Islands, corporate law has been a vehicle for this kind of economic growth and development.[484] As UKOTs, these jurisdictions benefit from their ties to the UK, such as the reputational advantage of being seen by investors as extensions of the UK.[485] Their economic success has led to a heightened standard of living for each of these jurisdictions, and has provided them with greater practical autonomy and authority over their daily governance with respect to the UK.[486]

Corporate Law as Decolonization

The Article does not seek to provide a grand theory of corporate law and decolonization for every former colony. Instead, it focuses the attention of scholars and policymakers in the developed world on the fact that colonialism and its progeny, neocolonialism, have forced postcolonial nations to find creative ways to survive and gain some of the freedoms decolonization promised in a competitive and hierarchical global economy.[487] One of these ways is through corporate law.[488] According to Caribbean legal scholar Rose-Marie Belle Antoine, [o]n the one hand, the development of [OFCs] in the Caribbean is a remarkable example of Caribbean talent, dedication, creativity and brilliance. On the other, the OFC phenomenon is a tragic reminder of a region [hindered] by a world view that has defined our political and economic policy.[489]
